Tube 300 mm (1 foot) long, 95 mm diameter (3 3/4 inch).
Threaded end caps.
I created it to hold water proof gear on back of motorcycle.
But it could be used for spaghetti storage, or anything you can use it for.

WPTube.stl is centre section, has push together fittings top and bottom, print 2 off and plug together.
WPTubeT.stl is top section with threads on top outside lip to accept screw on lid. Print 1 and plug on top of centre section.
WPTubeB.stl is bottom section with threads on bottom inside lip to accept screw on base. Print 1 and plug centre section onto top of it.
WPTubeTop.stl is screw lid. Print 1 off and screw onto top.
WPTubeBot.stl is screw base. Print 1 and screw onto base. I made it out of White PLA.
WP stands for 'Water Proofs'. A Water Proofs Tube.
Photos show sections before assembly, sections assembled (without end caps), final assembly with end caps, steel rule to illustrate size.
Just like the original Wobbly Table Wedge but a little bit bigger and with our You3Dit logo and name on the little widget.  Thanks cmceezee for such a useful little thing!

description.text: Cette pièce permet simplement de positionner facilement le support bobine fourni avec l'imprimante 3D Anet A8 en kit en hauteur. Ceci permet d'éliminer toute contrainte parasite au niveau de l'entrée du filament dans l'extrudeur, et positionner ainsi, il n'y a plus besoin de guide fil. Sa mise en place ne nécessite aucune modification des pièces d'origine de l'imprimante.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Layer Thikness : 0.3mm

Notes:

Pièce pour imprimante 3D Anet A8.

Conception

L'idée m'est venue après avoir assemblé ma nouvelle imprimante Anet A8. Cela ne me plaisait pas de laisser la bobine à hauteur de buse, sur le côté, placée ainsi, cela me semble plus naturelle. Et comme ça, pas besoin de guide fil.
J'ai réalisé la pièce sur Blender, en quelques heures.

Il faudra simplement démonter les deux visses supérieures de maintient de l'afficheur à cristaux liquides avant de mettre la pièce en place qui devrait s'intégrer toute seule. Une fois en place, il suffit de remettre les visses de maintient précédemment retirées. La durée d'impression à vitesse moyenne est d'environ 2h30mn

Things in my pocket keep pushing the buttons on my Cruze keys. Eventually it wears out the rubber buttons. So I made this. Just slip it in. Many interations, so the mesh is a nightmare. All done in TinkerCAD though... Print it with support. No rafts required.

An attempt to help with some layer noise/artifacts that may be due to lithophanes flexing while printing vertically. Also, just support for same to help prevent failed prints.

Helpers are 100mm tall by default. Scale on the Z axis to match your lithophane (ie for a 130mm tall litho, scale Z by 130% or 1.30). Avoid scaling on X or Y as well unless you really want the tabs and legs thicker and longer.

Place two helpers on either end of the litho. just touching each edge litho. model. Tabs should just make contact with the edge of the model. Helpers can be cut away when print is completed.

title: PLA Swing Thing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: PLA Swing Thing is a 3D printed PLA version of an apparently quite old design. Video of the PLA Swing Thing is here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u74y2vizy7U. This video is of the PLA Swing Thing with only 10 windings of the arm. A long (and perhaps boring to most) slow motion video studying the action of the PLA Swing Thing is here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nu57ssOsLyY. Notice the flex in "Rod.stl" as the ball bearing wraps around it, while "Tube Rubber Band.stl" remains relatively static. This video is of the PLA Swing Thing with 25 windings of the arm. A colleague sent me this video http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J-OY0KxRdgQ and asked if I could design a Swing Thing that was printable on a 3D printer. The PLA Swing Thing is the result. Note in the videos of the PLA Swing Thing, the PLA Swing Thing base was double sided taped to a heavy surface. If not secured properly, it will fall over, break, fly apart, do bad things, etc. Holding it down with a hand works, just keep away from the swinging ball bearing. Printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2 in PLA using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" settings.

Study "Assembly.skp". Obtain the following components: 1) Rubber band - un-stretched but flattened length of 130mm, width 7mm. I purchased a bag of assorted sized beige rubber bands ("Jot" is the only information on the bag) from an office supply store and many of these were inside. 2) Jumbo paper clips - One cut and bent to shape as in photo, the second for use as a tool for pulling the rubber band through "Tube Rubber Band.stl". 3) Ball bearing - 14.25mm (9/16"). I purchased mine at a local hardware store. 4) Sewing machine thread - about 120mm. I obtained mine from my wife's sewing kit. Print all the parts. Assemble the rubber band tube. Start by forcing the rubber band into the slot in "Mount Rubber Band.stl", then with the slot facing away from the slotted end of "Tube Rubber Band.stl", insert the rubber band into "Tube Rubber Band.stl" via the slotted end. Using an unfolded jumbo paper clip as a hook, pull the rubber band through the tube then slide "Mount Rubber Band.stl" into the slots in "Tube Rubber Band.stl". Next, push the rubber band through the collar end hole (the larger of the holes) on "Ball Arm Mount.stl" passed and clear of the hole for "Arm.stl", then slide "Arm.stl" into "Ball Arm Mount.stl". The rubber band should now be stretched around "Mount Rubber Band.stl", then through "Tube Rubber Band.stl", then around "Arm.stl", and "Ball Arm Mount.stl" should sit snugly on top of "Tube Rubber Band.stl". Test the assembly by winding the rubber band using the arm about 10 turns, then release. If the arm doesn't turn freely, petroleum jelly can be used around the collar of "Ball Arm Mount.stl". When complete, press the slotted end of the assembly into the larger of the two holes in "Base.stl", this is a very tight fit so a small bit of sanding and/or trimming with a modeling knife may be needed.
Press "Rod.stl" into the smaller of the two holes in "Base.stl". This also is a very tight fit so a small bit of sanding and/or trimming with a modeling knife may be needed. Press the ball bearing in "Ball Bearing Holder.stl". Depending on the color and machine settings, a little dish soap and light trimming of "Ball Bearing Holder.stl" with a modeling knife may work. However, I found using two ratchet wrench style sockets, the first being 1/2", and the second being 1/4", works best. Place the 1/2" socket standing on its end on a hard surface with the socket end facing up. Next, center "Ball Bearing Holder.stl" on the socket. Next, place the ball bearing on "Ball Bearing Holder.stl". Finally, using the 1/4" socket like a center punch, and a rubber mallet, gently tap the ball bearing into "Ball Bearing Holder.stl". Bend the jumbo paperclip into the shape shown in the photo.
Using about 120mm of sewing machine thread, tie one end to the jumbo paperclip hook, and the second to the "Ball Bearing Holder.stl", leaving about 100mm between the hook and the holder. I used cyanoacrylate to secure the knots. Make sure the small hole at the end of "Arm.stl" is vertical, then insert the hook into the small hole. To operate, unhook the ball bearing hook from the arm. Wind the arm about 8 to 10 turns, then release to see if that's enough winds for your rubber band to spin the arm about 8 times. If not, wind a few more times then try again. When successful, wind, hook the ball bearing to the arm, then holding the base securely with your hand, release the arm. I recommend safety glasses until you get the hang of it.

comments.text:
Huh... looks like the 'pendulum' part of the lower-tech version of a "Da Vinci Clock".
I'm not sure which one of these is more appropriately referred to as such and whether the tether (heh) idea originated with him (it's certainly fitting), but I actually used to own this exact model, here:
https://i.imgur.com/Rw6GiGx.jpg
and it came straight from the Da Vinci museum in Vinci, Italy. Chintzy crap that hardly worked worth a damn and mostly just took up space and got caught on things... but whatever. Neat to recognize it all these years later. However, I also saw this when Googling "Da Vinci Clock":
https://i.imgur.com/Rw6GiGx.jpg
and that looks a hell of a lot more like something worthy of his name. <_<
comments.author: Medlam

comments.text: I love this mechanism. I first became aware of it as a clock escapement mechanism. It was invented in the late 1800's and was called a Flying Pendulum Clock, otherwise known as an Ignatz movement. The clock mechanisn had a slightly different look, due to the presence of two posts and two downward-hanging short posts.

description.text: At the risk of offending, I am uploading this guitar pick to share with the world. 3D printed guitar picks give you the freedom to design exactly what you want in your hand while you are playing. And I guess this speaks volumes. I suppose this model will be deleted someday.

Printer:

Prusa MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100% (doesn't matter)

Notes:

Printed with the purest of intentions.

I used Fusion 360

I started with a rectangle sized the same width and length as a guitar pick out of my drawer of picks. Then I extruded it up 0.5mm. I then filleted the top two corners 10mm each. Then I constructed an arch starting from the bottom of the left fillet end to the middle of the bottom edge. Then completed a plane around the left corner of the rectangle, extruded the plain downward 0.5mm with a cut directive. I did a matching arc on the right side and repeated the process.

Then I drew the penis from memory of having one of my own for 46 years (yes I am 12 years old mentally) using the spline line tool. It took a few tries and honestly it barely resembles my own or any other I've run across at the gym. Still in a cartoonish sort of way for an amateur, I think it will suffice.

This is an adjustable endstop mount for the Z-axis on my FolgerTech 2020.

Two pieces clamp around the head of a button-head screw at the top of the main body, constraining it in place, but allowing it to be rotated. The central hole in the topmost "sandwich" piece allows you to turn the screw. It drives a captive nut that slots into the back of the shuttle / mount. The screw must be long enough to go through the central hole in the bottom of the main body, otherwise there would be some undue play in the shuttle / mount.

You'll need m3 x .5 scews and nuts. I was able to get the nuts to fit tight enough to stay with the part during assembly and disassembly. Hopefully you'll achieve the same.

title: Pistol Picatinny Rail for Red Dot Sight and Flashlight

description.text:
I remixed ngray1519's pistol red dot sight mount to better fit my Glock 19 and cheap $18 Amazon red dot sight and to add a bottom rail so that I could attach my Streamlight TLR-3 flashlight.

I also modified the section that attaches to the rail of the Glock so that it is at a 2 degree angle. I did this because I noticed the Glock rail plastic was not perfectly horizontal and so the 2 degree angle allowed the red dot sight to stay horizontal. Not sure if this will be the case with other Glocks so your mileage may vary.

I also added an extra picatinny rail slot towards the front so that I could mount my red dot further forward since my particular red dot is pretty long and was hanging off the back of the picatinny rail.

The original sight mount designed by ngray1519 would attach to the Glock's flashlight/laser mount and thus not allow you to mount a flashlight/laser so I added a rail to the bottom of the mount that mimics the rail on the Glock to allow me to mount my Streamlight TLR-3 flashlight. I also wanted to have a nut for the screw as well as have both the screw head and nut sit flush in the mount. I used an M3 screw with an M3 nut. I forget what length but I believe it was an M3x25 or M3x30.

I took this setup to the range, zeroed my cheap red dot at ~6 yards and it held zero at that distance very well! I was very surprised. The heat from the barrel did not affect the mount in any way.

The pistol stand in the picture is this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2753339

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You probably do not have to print it with 100% infill but I did just to make sure it would hold zero.

I recommend printing this with the picatinny rail UP and the flashlight rail DOWN. Basically in the same orientation as how you would put it on your pistol.

I used a lot of supports but just because Slic3r does not allow me to selectively place supports where I want them. It's all or nothing. You may be able to get away with just a few supports.

Most 3d printers equipped with beds suspended by a screw-spring combination have movement most noticeable in the Y direction. It's frustrating; especially so on larger volume printers with heavy beds. Not satisfied with the parts available to fix this issue, I designed my own to mitigate Y movement while still allowing for flex in the Z direction (for bed leveling).

These types of print beds are sway structures, like a tall deck on a house, which influenced the geometry and my design.

There are 2 files designed specifically for the CR-10, but scaling the model could make it usable for all print beds. Determine your needed distance then use your preferred tool for scaling.

If there are specific requests, let me know and I will try to get to them. Also, for the sake of improvement, please let me know how this works for you!

Printer:

CR-10 Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

3.0

Infill:

20

Installation:
1) Remove glass bed (if applicable)
2) Removal of one screw and spring per side is necessary
3) The fit should be snug, but sanding or filing may be needed. If the fit is too loose, add small pieces of tape or craft foam.

If using that X-axis brace, it can be situated in your preferred location( against the bed, against the mounting plate, between the Y Sway Bars mounts.

This is a simple case for 2 Samsung Galaxy S4 Batteries. the 2mm thick Plate goes between the batteries. As shown in the photos, I have soldered the connections in Parallel to give 3.7v and 5,200mAh for a project.

Update:
I have finally completed my project with this as the last part. there is just enough room inside the box for the cables to be knotted on the inside of the cable path to give it more durability when cables are pulled from the outside. as you can see i also used quite a bit of hot glue to ensure no metal to metal connections are made at the top of the batteries.

again, i used a drill and crafting knives to cut out the cable path.

i also had to make some adjustments on the tabs for the lid to close correctly. the openings on the bottom printed a bit narrower than designed.

I formerly used this smartphone magnetic mount with a CD slot dashboard mount. But after seeing a much more portable version that sticks into your A/C vent, I modeled this after those products.

Great for travel! You will need to get the magnetic head separately that attaches to this mount. Because I already had one, I didn't model the entire thing.

You can search on amazon for this and you'll get a ton of matches, even just the magnetic portion itself.

To attach the magnetic head to it, read the post-printing section below.

Assembly

Once you remove the supports:

You'll need a #4 screw 3/8" long (inserted from the prong side of the vent mount). With screw inserted, you will be able to screw the magnet head to it.

I hammered the screw through the prongs of the mount a little, then just used an allen key to fully engage the screw so that it protruded to the other side. Now that the threads stick out, I removed the magnetic head off the other mount, and just screwed it on via its metal plate.

This particular model happened to use the same screw threads!

Mounting plate for a rotary encoder.  Used on our 2014 FIRST Robotics Competition robot custom drivetrain gearboxes.

This is a "floating" camera mount for Tech2Cs awesome Peon230 - Quadcopter (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:629338). I wanted to use FPV as well as capture HD footage but I didn't want to add to the weight from adding a second camera, so I used the RunCam Split 2. Only one problem, although the Split 2 can capture awesome HD footage the internal mounting plate absorbs zero vibrations or any of the other bumps you can take while flying. So I drew up this "Floating" Camera Mount, I made it use four anti vibration rubber balls instead of the normal three once it has to hold the mounting plate vertical and I didn't want it sagging. I made two versions, one has a full back plate and the other has a wire pass through on the bottom if you can't or don't want to run the wire to the side of it. The holes to mount the camera bracket are 12mm apart so they will fit nicely in the 6 to 19 mm range most brackets offer, also nuts are not required as the mounting holes fit tight on a standard 3mm screw. Another nice feature is with how far forward it's pushing the camera, the blades are not in the camera shot even with the super wide angle of the split 2. The anti vibration balls I used can be found here - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01NCQFPXQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1 .

title: Max's Antler (from How the Grinch Stole Christmas)

description.text: This design is based on the antler made by the Grinch for Max in the 60's TV special "How the Grinch Stole Christmas". The antler is intended to be printed hollow (0% Infill) and the two antler parts glued together. All parts should be printed with supports touching the build plate only. The base is aligned with the antler using two #6 x 1/2" flat head screws and glued. Any of the holes can be used to achieve a good fit, but the intent was to align to the forward holes. The strap I used was a tennis shoe lace that was looped and fed downward thru the center slots.

title: OpenSCAD ISO metric thread library / functions

description.text:
Allows creation of standard nuts and bolts or allow threads to be included in projects.
THIS IS OLD VERSION, please see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:311031

top of file includes calls to make bolts: M10x16, M8x16, M6x12 nuts: M10, M8, M6. simply uncomment a line and build then print, or create your own sizes or include into your own project so you can have threads.
Photos should show black and white nuts and bolts in M6, M8 and M10 sizes, black versions are standard bought steel, white versions are ones I printed in white ABS.
I have a Reprap Metric Mendel Prusa with LM8UU bearings, fishbone wade extruder, own design hot-end, MKII hot bed. Only got it going yesterday, not yet calibrated awaiting micrometer from ebay.
This is my first design in OpenSCAD, maths in not my strong point, but I think these are as close to accurate ISO Metric as I can get. Hot-end has 0.5mm extrusion hole, used 0.2mm layers, I had to go down to 5mm/s speed to get these printed, I have not yet tried smaller sizes. OK, so that was a shock, knocked up the original file quickly for self-use, uploaded as an after thought, did not expect that much interest!
There have been some concerns with CGAL rendering times with bolts.
So, see new version IsoThread_20120823.scad.
I have moved positional calculations into variables to they are now calculated only one per thread part and I have now included quality tables. Results:
CGAL Rendering times

M8 nut 9 secs

M6x12 7 mins 27 secs
Ubuntu 10.04 LTS - OpenSCAD 2012.02.28:
M10 nut 4 secs
M8 nut 4 secs
M6 nut 2 secs

comments.text:
Hi
I am looking for a way to create a cylinder (internal diameter 54mm, wall thickness 1mm - so it will need to be a fine thread) with a thread on the inside (this is for several parts of a model rocket). This is by far the easiest scad thread library to understand (I am an scad neophyte), but I am having difficulty in seeing how to do this by modifying your library. Any hints would be most appreciated!
Tks
comments.author: CrispinH

comments.text:
Hi Crispin,
Duh, I'm going nuts....
To put a thread on the inside (as you actually said), use this line instead:
translate([0,0,45]) thread_in_pitch(54,5,0.5);
The translate moves up to 5 mm before top of cylinder.
It creates a thread of 54 mm (inside diameter) that is 5 mm long (high) with pitch of 0.5.
comments.author: CrispinH

comments.text:
Hi Crispin,
Please don't use this old version, click on Remixes and go to the updated version. This version was the very first thing I created in OpenSCAD, updated version is much cleaner and easier:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:311031http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
You need to put my file either in the library directory or same directory as your file.
Then, to use the library, put this line at the top of your file:
use <isothread.scad>
To create a cylinder with sizes you gave, you will need something like:
difference()
{
cylinder(r=56/2,h=50);
translate([0,0,-0.1]) cylinder(r=54/2,h=50.2);
}
This creates a cylinder with diameter 56 mm then subtracts a cylinder of diameter 54 from it.
Then you need to add the thread like this:
translate([0,0,45]) thread_out_pitch(56.5,5,0.5);
The translate moves up to 5 mm before top of cylinder.
It creates a thread of 56.5 mm (56 mm inside diameter + 0.5 inch thread size) that is 5 mm long (high) with pitch of 0.5.
I think you may find printing to be a challenge.
Cylinder wall thickness of 1 mm will be hard.
Thread of pitch 0.5 will be very hard.
You may need to re-think.
You could also see my other thing Big Tube:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27181http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
I think this may be close to what you need as a starting point.

comments.text: I need to use this to make a nut and bolt that are thread size 13 with the nut's internal diameter 19mm (to fit shower head).  What do I input for this?
comments.author: gwfami

comments.text:
Um, your problem does not compute!
hex_nut(13);
will give you a standard ISO 13 mm thread
hex_bolt(13,20);
will give you a standard ISO 13 mm bolt that is 20 mm long
All threads have a coarseness index, that is how deep the grooves are, which also relates to pitch (length between 1 ridge and the next).
Most ISO threads are either fine or coarse, at 13 mm you are usually saying thread is 0.75 mm or 1 mm respectively.
But normally the threaded part of a 13 mm bolt has outside diameter of 13 mm + coarse (13.75 or 14 mm) and inside diameter of a 13 mm nut is 13 mm - coarse (12.25 mm or 12 mm ).
So 13 mm thread with an inside diameter of 19 mm is not possible.
comments.author: gwfami

comments.author: gwfami

comments.text: One way I found to speed this library up is to generate shorter lengths (just a couple of turns of the threads), then duplicate this shape and translate and rotate it a bit so it forms the next part of the thread.  Keep doing this a few times and you end up with a longer thread which renders quite quickly.  Each generated section is cached then reused, so it is much quicker.  One quick calculation I did showed that a render I was attempting would have taken 3 years (as the time goes up geometrically).  However, I got it down to a few minutes.

title: Horizontal Spool Filament Twister (Parametric, Fully Printable)

description.text:
This was an attempt to make a fully printable spool holder with no moving parts, but it seems to have one large flaw. Every time one loop of filament comes off the side it adds a twist. After some time (maybe 30min printing) the twists make a big tangle stopping the print. So far I don't really have any idea how to fix it, but I'll leave the design here in case someone wants it for short prints or something.

This is a horizontal spool holder that requires no moving parts and is fully 3d printable. So far it has only been tested with a PLA roll, but is seems to be working fine. The filament is quite easy to pull off the spool sideways so I think this should be no problem for any extruder.

I would recommend making the screw as tall as your printer will allow since the filament seems to move more smoothly the higher the filament guide stands. If you want to move it lower this is easily done after the fact by screwing the nuts further down. To lock the filament guide in place simply screw the lower nut upwards and the upper nut downwards squeezing the filament guide in between.

Also, thanks to NUT JOB for his great parametric nuts and bolts library: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed with 0.2 mm layers, 10% infill and 4mm brims with PLA and it seems to be fine. The screw is not very rigid, but this shouldn't be a problem because the forces on the filament guide should be very small.

Only a small part of the filament guide toroid might need some support, but the rest can be printed without.

Stand for the Innokin MVP4. Slot allows chargin.
One of my Favorite Batman Cartoons. And the Batarang Design is really Sick.

The TL;DR of it is I have a reasonably nice Thermaltake computer tower that has some really crappy plastic feet that clip into some plain-ish 10mm holes through the bottom of the case, and the clips on them are breaking off, probably because it's really crappy plastic that are only clip-fit into a sheet metal case, which can spin, and the metal starts to score the plastic, breaking off the clips.

This version is essentially a 1:1 design of the injection-molded feet that come with it. I might attempt another version that screws or get screwed or bolted into the case somehow, depending on how well these hold up.

AutoCAD

DWG is provided.

It's as basic as it looks. I essentially layered a number of cylinders together and then performed boolean union or subtraction operations on them. Clips were made by chamfering a cylinder of the max radius to make the profile, and then measuring a 4mm box with it's central "axis" aligned with the axis of the cylinders, and then placing four boxes aligned diagonally against that center box, and then subtracting the four boxes from the chamfered cylinder. think of a 2d tick-tack-toe board placed within the footprint of the cylinder diameter. the center square is the alignment 4mm box. the outside corners are what get removed. the top/left/right/bottom squares remain. It probably took me longer to write this blurb about it than to do it, and it was the most "difficult" thing on the part.

I don't know why I wrote this block of text.

print_settings.Notes:: General print speed was 30-35mm/sec using PLA filament.

title: A1010 Gotek
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This allows the reuse of an old Amiga A1010 external floppy drive by inserting a Gotek PCB. The fascia accepts a rotary encoder, 0.91" OLED display (hot glued in place), and relocation of the activity and 'power on' LEDs (3mm), also hot glued into place.
The selection push buttons only protrude from the fascia about 0.50mm but can still be used.

I added a fascia without the rotary encoder hole, I also moved the LED holes to the stock position above the two selection buttons.

The project consists of a PCB mounting tray and the fascia.

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm-.25mm

Infill:

15%-25%

Notes:

General print speed was 30-35mm/sec using PLA filament.

Solidworks 2015

Using no more than a cheap pair of digital calipers ($20), a steel rule, and SolidWorks 2015 to reverse engineer the stock front fascia. I did not include a draft angles the were present in the original injection molded fascia. In the future I may use a CMM to more accurately model the fascia.
The process involved 4 iterations of prints, each taking 3.5 to 4 hours to print.

title: CR-10 S5 Y Axis Limit Switch Bracket

description.text:
This Y Axis Limit Switch Mounting Bracket for the Creality CR-10 S5 is different then the OEM bracket supplied with the printer to overcome two major shortcomings. The OEM bracket cannot be adjusted far enough back to center the table on the Y Axis, and it will not allow full 500mm table travel.

There is more information explaining this issue here: http://www.curtronics.com/3Dprinting/YLimit/

WARNING: One very important thing to note: The distance from the top of the aluminum extrusion the bracket is mounted on to the underside of the table carriage is very small, under 0.150" on my printer, yours may vary. The thickness of the top of the new bracket thet sits on top of the rail is 0.125". Yes not much clearance. If you are going to install this bracket on your printer make absolutely sure the carriage does not hit and/or get stopped by the bracket before powering up your printer.

author: __Vincent__

description.text: Great model by C4robotics, the only issue I have with it is that the pegs for the body alignment are on the top half which means you have to print it with a lot of additional supports. Plus the alignment pegs didn't look like they actually aligned. Additionally the lower half of the body is elevated as well. I made a remix where I swapped the alignment pegs so they are on the lower half and the bottom of the body now sits flush on the ground. I did scale up the model 550% so if people use my remix keep that in mind for the rest of the pieces. Thank you C4robotics for a great model!
I wish I could add his signature laugh to this prop but unfortunately I cant

https://youtu.be/e1FdlGJd-1s

I don't like the stock dial buttons for the X-Wing game, and all of the ones on here either require you don't use the identifier dial, or wants you to cut the name out. I designed this one to print out in about 15 minutes, press fit, hold the name dial in place and not require you cut anything out. If you wanted to take it back apart and put the original button back on there's no reason you couldn't.

This was designed to only use two perimeters in most places with a .4 nozzle to minimize plastic. I printed this one in fake marble PLA at 200 on the hotend and nothing on the heated bed. You do need a pretty dialed in printer, I'd imagine.

Godit82 had some of these printed and they were a bit too tight to spin the movement dial once pressed together. I'll also point out that once pressed together, they will likely not come apart without breaking. I've uploaded a version with looser tolerances to make the dial move more smoothly. If you're having trouble with the original version or if you're sending out for prints, choose this version.

I've included some photos showing the differences in measurements I ended up with after reprinting (on a different printer than before). The youtube clip is me showing that while it's a little more loose, it's not a major gap.

comments.text: So I went all in and ordered enough of these for my entire collection plus some (40 set) and the price with shipping came out to about $0.70 per set. But the printers must have been worried about scrapping such small parts because they actually sent me 50 dial in total so not a bad deal at all.
comments.author: Godit82

comments.text: I edited the model a bit to eliminate the issues you were having - you can see the difference in the youtube video I put up. Mine mostly spin fine but I have a few that are a bit tight, and I've found you can't separate the pieces without breaking it. I had intended these to be something cheap someone was churning out on their home 3d printer, I do apologize if it cost you a bit, I didn't take into mind people paying to have them printed. Hopefully the looser files will help if it comes up again.
comments.author: Godit82

comments.text: Oh no worries friend. I assumed they were somewhat disposalable as well so my money is not wasted. The ones that are tight for me I found I could sand down the entire front face just enough so that the dial sits a millimeter above the ring which is enough for my thumb to grip and turn. I will happily make use of what I’ve got and I’m glad I could help make the design even better.

comments.text: Thanks for the compliment, and if you get some made I hope they work out for you. I don't have any experience with commercial printing services so I can't really help with suggestions. The marble color on this comes from small flecks inside the filament I bought.

title: Real 1" Snap Fort Kids PVC Kit Toy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
So, the first model i made of this was .... .... ... pretty, and i found out it didn't work, at least not without flexible filament, and i didn't include a wrench either.. That was over a year ago... so

I present to the world, a NEW and IMPROVED modular 1 inch PVC fortress kit (now with working physics and wrench!)

but that title was too long.

When i was a kid, i used to play with "Playskool Pipeworks" and make cars and trains and helicopters and cranes and all sorts of stuff. (look it up)

Those don't exist anymore, not really (some knockoffs that are only for fort creation, not structural at all)

With this set, i hope to add more features to make "Panels" possible, or at least make something you could ride down a hill.

All files are separated, but the kit would be assembled as in the picture (from onshape, but will upload real prints soon)

it would take a 1/4 in drill bit (or a 6 mm drill bit) and a little time, but the end result is going to be awesome, so i personally think its worth the time for my daughter.

How to:

  1. buy 1 in PVC pipe and joints to your hearts content
  2. fit together
  3. measure 1 in from pipe edge (or use Drill Measure printable, refer to picture containing part)
  4. drill hole straight through all pieces desired (uniformity makes the kit more modular, and able to be "rebuilt" differently with ease, like "always drill vertically when joints are laying flat", but i'll upload a video once i get a few printed that shows off the pointers better)
  5. mark exactly halfway between both holes along outside edge (per drilled item)
  6. drill hole through both points marked
  7. insert spring joint part
    8 (optionally) insert tension rods in + shape
  8. (optionally) cut holes for, and insert PVC end cap, and glue to tension rod

I know that's a lot, but i always want people to have....

happy printing!!

Refer to description text

Above has a how to, but expect another youtube link to a build video if you ned, but it'll be a couple days to get enough printed to show off what i know this can be/do.

short version, have a drill and pencil and measuring tool/string handy (pieces all fit at 1" depth from end of pvc)

comments.text: I've printed Several of the "clasps" and will be fitting them soon (i updated the STL to allow an easier installation, it's more "sproingy" now)

three of his marks in a row (horizontally, vertically or diagonally)

author: jhbutch

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:270289 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=270289

Hello everyone.
I have converted my MegaTronXY X1 into a CoreXY Printer.
The printing area is 400x450x370
I read all about how fast the corexy printers print so I wanted to take a shot at it.
So I tock my MegaTronXY X1 printer frame and I made it into a CoreXY printer.
the Ramps full Graphic Display 12864 Case and Mount can be found here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1343964
any Ramps1.4 case will work, I just wanted to use the Graphics display from above to make it easy to adjust the screen.

I have 3 types of Anti-wobble inserts to add which stop any and all wobble. you can either drill out the Z_stage_carriage_100mm v2 or edit it to have the anti wobble inserted in the carriage platform, I just drilled it out and then glued it in place once I leveled the carriage.

This conversion uses the same frame mounts found on my MegaTronXY X1 and parts/supplies from Lowes and Home Depot.
This can be built with either 3/4 aluminum square tubing or 1 inch square tubing. the frame mounts are scalable. just resize for 3/4 tubing.
You can also use the 3/8 aluminum rods from Home Depot and Lowes, they may be .5 mm's smaller but they work just as well.
You can look at my MegaTronXY X1 here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2326560 and check out the tubing mounts.
and I borrowed the X and Y stepper mounts from here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1849704
I've made some changes to the Z axis bed support and there is no wobble what so ever. I've also added level springs and screws to make the bed level. Haven't needed a auto level install since I can adjust the bed.
Everything was made from 3/4 square tubing or 1 inch square tubing which you can get at home depot or Lowes.
the heatbed consist of 4 120 watt glued on mk heat plates which can be purchased on Ebay or any 3d printer supply store.
They were glued on with Fireplace caulk which can also be purchased at home depot or Lowes, the screws were 3/4 and 1 inch self drilling metal screws again purchase at Home Depot or Lowes.
This model consist of 3 400 watt power supplies 2 of which are used for the heat bed and connected to the ramps 1.4 board with 12 volt automotive relays which are rated at 60 amps each at 14.4 vdc. the 3rd power supply runs the extruder and motors along with L.E.D. leds to light up the bed.
Heating the bed doesn't take very long. The relays have their very own fans to keep them cool.
On a side note, The Bed Z Motors are wired together in series to evenly raise and lower the bed.

I'll be adding a new Hot end extruder Platform on a later date. This update will allow you to make adjusting the belts on the fly

After test printing for more then 12 hours I found out the printed Anti-Wobble inserts failed. So I still use them in conjunction the Brass Lead Screw I was able to keep the anti-wobble working. and printing for another 12 hours the wobble still didn't come in to play at all.
So I just drilled out 3/8 hole so I could insert the Brass Lead screw and it worked. Please see Anti-Wobble Brass inset picture.

12-23-2017: I've updated the Z Axis Carriage to a more wider and stable platform.
This new platform increases the stability and level of the bed.
I've also updated the Hotend Carriage to wider and longer GT2 belt holder.
I've also added y Bearing stabilizer and anti belt slip off.

title: Prusa mk3 Einsy case with fan

description.text:
This is a small modification on the stock Prusa i3 Mk3 Einsy base and door to accommodate a 40x40x10mm Noctua fan. You'll need two 3mm bolts (about 15mm long I would guess) and nuts. Mount the fan so it blows out as an exhaust. It takes the stock hinge, you will need to print one of those if not upgrading.

Recommend PETG or ABS. I used Atomic Filament Carbon Fiber PETG.

I've printed it and it prints fine, fan fits great and the door clears, but can't actually test it until my mk2 -> mk3 upgrade kit arrives. Since those don't seem to be shipping for quite a while, I thought I would upload this in the meanwhile so others can make use of it.

Finding 12v power is still a question because I don't have an Einsy board yet. If anyone figures out a good spot to tap off power, please leave a comment! Fallback plan is to connect it to 24V with a 240 Ohm (or whatever the next highest common value is) resistor.

author: Demonocolips

description.text:
Design for an adjustable connector to fit two 1010 type T-slot rails together. Still at early WIP stage, so some other pieces may change. Most likely putting on some holes for nuts or bolts (needed) and an alternate hinge piece with an anchor base on it.

Yes there's another hinge for T-slot rails, but if you look at it it seems to be for a different application. In this case it's setting the angle for T-slot rails end-to-end, which I think will be useful in other ways.

The hinge itself will be held together with a nut & bolt and some washers, but they're not pictured in the current render.

But the main idea here is to use commonly available T-slot rails as a base for an assembly jig. So this would allow you to set an angle for various parts, while inserts that go into the T-slots would hold various model parts together for assembly and gluing. (Focus on RC or model aircraft stuff.) That's going to be another project though.

And if you like these kind of things and would like to see them keep coming, any little bit of spare change can help. Don't need much, but a little something. https://www.patreon.com/pauljs75

--- Edit ---
Added an alternate spacer piece for the hinge. This part allows anchoring or supporting the hinge pivot upon another surface.

--- Edit ---
Revised hinge halves. Now with places for some nuts to insert, and a rounded end to guide in easier.

--- Part Cross Reference ---
Added a new thing. :) This is an adjustable jig stand piece that is made to mount to T-slot railing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2722728

--- Edit ---
Another revision. Same parts but should be to a different scale. (Hopefully) The Rev1 parts are still based off the imperial measures I referenced, but converted to mm. (So 2.54mm to fit a 1" sized rail.) Even if that's now correct, I can't guarantee what adjustments may be needed to get into tolerance - so they may require some finishing like light sanding.

worlds 7th atomic power

A totally overkill (without any killing) mousetrap. When a mouse or other small varmint steps on a switch inside the bottle, a microcontroller activates a servo to close the door (or doors) on the bottle, trapping the critter inside and sending an alert over WiFi letting you know that the trap has been sprung. This project was built using an Adafruit Huzzah ESP8266 WiFi microcontroller breakout board, but could be controlled using any microcontroller capable of digital/analogue input and servo control. I have included code written for and tested on an Adafruit Huzzah ESP8266 (WiFi), and an Adafruit Pro Trinket 5v (No WiFi).

Parts List:

  • Microcontroller - Adafruit Huzzah ESP8266 (WiFi) or Adafruit Pro Trinket 5v (no WiFi) ~$11 - $13 CAD
  • Servo - 2.5g Goteck Metal Gear Micro Servo GS-9025MG ~$9 CAD
  • Plastic bottle with 1.5" neck - common juice bottle size. (Ocean Spray, Sunripe, etc)
  • 24 AWG silicon insulated wire (do not use wire with soy based insulation as rodents will chew on it) ~$1.50 CAD for 3m
  • Shrink tubing for 24 AWG wire
  • Music wire - 1/32", 3/64", or 1/16" should work
  • 2x 6-32 3/4" screws and washers
  • 2x 6-32 3/8" screws and washers - it may be helpful to go with longer screws and cut/grind them to length
  • 5v DC Power supply - 1A minimum
  • #6 Ring Terminal (optional) ~$2.50 CAD for pack of 6
  • Female jumper wires (optional) ~$2.50 CAD for pack of 20

Tools & Supplies:

  • A computer - for modifying and upload code to your microcontroller.
  • FTDI Cable - for uploading code to the microcontroller.
  • Soldering Iron and solder.
  • Butane/propane torch, lighter, or heat gun (optional).
  • Screw driver(s).
  • Glue - I recommend two part epoxy with 30 - 45 min working time.
  • Pliers - for bending the servo control rod.
  • Drill and drill bit - for resizing holes in the servo horns.
  • Barbecue skewer

Instructions:

  1. Let's get your microcontroller programmed before any wires get connected. Check out the Adafruit Huzzah ESP8266 setup guide, or the Adafruit Pro Trinket setup guide. These guides will get you familiar with your microcontroller, walk you through driver installation, Arduino IDE installation and software library setup, and show you how to program your microcontroller. When you're comfortable with how everything works, come back here for the next step.

  2. For Adafruit Pro Trinket (and other non WiFi boards):
    Open the "Mouse_Trap_Pro_Trinket.ino" file in your Arduino IDE and upload the code to the Pro Tinket. The value on lines 27 and 28 is a mid point to centre the servo before attaching the servo horn. These values will be changed later.

  3. For Adafruit Huzzah ESP8266:
    Open the "Mouse_Trap_Huzzah_ESP8266.ino" file in your Arduino IDE enter your network's SSID on line 41, your network password on line 42, give your Huzzah a static IP address on line 45, also enter your network's gateway and subnet on line 45 and hit the upload button to send the code to your Huzzah ESP8266. The value on lines 56 and 57 is a mid point to centre the servo before attaching the servo horn. These values will be changed later.

    When the Huzzah board is powered up the following LED sequences should occur: Solid Red and blinking Blue LED means the board is trying to connect to your Wifi, Red and Blue alternating blinking lets you know the board is connected to your WiFi and the trap door(s) is/are about to open, Solid Blue LED indicates the trap is ready and waiting to catch something.

    The board needs to be connected to WiFi in order for the trap to work properly. If the connection is interrupted, the board will run the reconnect function, preventing the microcontroller from checking the status of the switch. Iv'e tried writing the code a few different ways to prevent this from happening but haven't had any luck so far. See the troublshooting guide at the end of these instructions.

  4. Print the switch base, switch top, and the contact template. Run wire through the middle hole in the switch base and then through the switch top.

  5. Use the contact template to trace a circle on some thin sheet metal and cut the circle out using some tin snips. The metal should be electrically conductive and solderable. If using a soup can lid, remove the plastic coating from the inside of the lid with sand paper before soldering.



  6. Test fit the contact plate in the switch top. Cut, sand, or file away material until the contact fits in the switch top. Mark the orientation of the circle where the wire will be soldered.

  7. Solder the end of the wire to the contact and insert the contact in to the switch pulling the slack out of the wire.

  8. Apply glue around the edge of the contact plate, in the wire channel, and glue the switch top to the switch base. I use two part epoxy with 30 - 45 min working time.

  9. The switch top should make contact with the switch base with 8 - 12 grams of force ( about the weight of 2 or three Canadian quarters). You can pull up on the switch top to bend the spring portion and give the switch more tension/travel, or use a torch to slightly melt the spring portion to give the switch less tension/travel, or adjust the length of the contact screw when the switch is installed in the bottle.

  10. I heated a centre punch with a torch to melt holes in the bottle for ventilation, and three holes to mount the switch and pass the wire though. Measure twice and cut... err... melt once.

  11. Crimp a ring terminal to the end of some wire. The wire will need to reach the controll board when it is installed, so cut it a few centimetres longer then the reach to the bottle opening and trim it to length later. Secure the switch to the inside of the bottle using the 3/8" 6-32 screws placing the ring terminal on the screw at the contact end of the switch. I used a barbecue skewer to hold the switch in place wile fastening the first screw. Make sure the screw on the contact side of the switch will touch the contact plate when the switch is depressed. If the contact plate is touching the screw without being pushed down, cut or grind the screw to the correct lenght, or add washers to back it away from the contact plate.

  12. Set the bottle and switch aside for now. It's time to assemble the working end of the trap. Decide weather you want a base plate with or without legs, and single door or double door and print the parts along with the threaded ring. If using a Goteck Metal Gear servo, also print the servo horn. I prototyped this trap using a hitec hs-55 servo, but found the Goteck servo to be smoother, more reliable and accurate at a comparable price.

  13. Place the threaded ring in the base plate, then screw the door(s) to the base plate using 6-32 3/4" screws and washers. Tighten the screw until the doors will no longer swing freely, then back the screws off just enough to let the doors swing without any resistance. Next, insert the servo and screw it to the base plate.

  14. To keep things tidy, I cut three female jumper wires in half, shortened the servo leads, and soldered the jumper wires to the servo leads and covered the joint with shrink tube. You could do without the jumper wires by soldering the servo leads directly to the microcontroller board.

  15. If using a Huzzah ESP8266 breakout board, attach the servo's black wire to ground, red to V+, and yellow to pin 12. For a Pro Trinket, the black wire goes to ground, red to BUS, and yellow to pin 9.

  16. Place the base plate on the bottle and tighten the threaded ring making sure to align the feet with the bottle face that has the switch.

  17. Drill the holes in the servo control horn and the holes in the door(s) control arm slightly larger than the music wire. Bend and cut a piece of music wire to make a z shaped push rod approximately 24mm in length, and insert one end in the servo horn and and the other in the the door(s) control arm. Apply power to the microcontroller and let the servo center itself. Open the door(s) halfway and put the servo control horn on the servo and use the screw that came with the servo to hold it in place.

  18. Now open the code in the Arduino IDE again to set the servo positions for fully open and fully closed. This will be a trial and error process that will take some time to get just right. First increase the servoOpen parameter by increments of 10 on line 56 of the Huzzah code, or line 27 of the Pro Trinket code and upload the code to your micro controller. Repeat this process until the door(s) just clear the opening of the bottle. Then decrease the value by increments of one or two to get the open position just right. The edge of the door(s) shouldn't go beyond the inner opening of the bottle.

  19. Next, decrease the servoClosed parameter by increments of 10 on line 57 of the Huzzah code, and bridge the second ground pin with pin 14, or line 28 of the Pro Trinket code, and bridge ground with pin 11, and upload the code to your microcontroller. Repeat this until the servo closes the door fully and you can hear the servo binding. Now increase the value by one or two until the door is fully close without any servo binding.

  20. One wire from the switch can be cut to length and attached to pin 14 on the Huzzah ESP8266, or pin 11 on the Pro Trinket. The other wire from the switch can be cut to length and connected to the second ground pin of the Huzzah ESP8266. The Pro Trinket only has one ground pin, so you could use a two pin jumper extension to attach the servo wire and switch wire to the ground pin (which is what I did), or modify the code to set a digital pin low and use it as a ground pin for the switch. Again, I used female jumper wires for these connections.

  21. Bait the trap. The internet seems to agree that peanut butter is the best bait for mice, and I've found it to work well. I use a barbecue skewer to place a ball of peanut butter in the bottom of the bottle. Try not to get any on the sides of the bottle; a mouse may get a meal without having to walk over the switch. I'm thinking that using 1oz paper cups, often found in fast food restaurants, would do a great job of containing the bait, making cleanup much easier. I didn't clean the bottle after catching a couple mice and after about a month a new mouse came along but didn't show any interest in the trap until I cleaned it and baited it with some fresh peanut butter.

  22. If you used a Pro Tinket, your done! Just set the trap where you know mice frequently pass by. You can use a USB power adaptor with a micro USB calbe, or a battery with a sufficiently large capacity to keep the trap powered until it's time to recharge. Check the trap at least once a day. You can set up a networked camera to check the trap from your computer, phone, or tablet.

  23. If you used a Huzza ESP8266, you'll need to power the board using an FTDI cable or cut the end off a USB cable and solder female jumber wires to the positive and negative wires and connect them to the 5v and ground pins of the FTDI header.

    With the board powered up, log in to a web browser and type the IP address of the Huzzah in to the browser's address bar to check the status of the trap. It's still a good idea to do a physical check of the trap daily just to be sure everything is working.

Troubleshooting the Huzzah ESP8266:

  • In the code for the Huzzah board, there are lines that give output to the Arduino IDE serial monitor. Uncomment the line that starts with "Serial.begin", and any line that starts wih "Serial.println" by removing the "//" at the beginning of the line. Then go to Tools --> Serial Monitor, and upload the code to your Huzzah. Some helpful info will show up to help you figure out what is going wrong with the code.

  • If the board will not connect to your network when power is first applied, try disconnecting power and plugging it back in. It seems that timing of the initial connection is finicky. It will either connect shortly after powering up, or not at all.

  • As mentioned earlier in the instructions, if WiFi is enabled in the code, the Huzzah board needs to maintain a network connection to catch a mouse. If a mouse steps on the switch while the board is trying to reconnect, the microcontroller will miss it. If you have frequent WiFi dropouts, you may wish to disable the WiFi in the Huzzah code. This will make it function just like any arduino without a WiFi connection, and will make the trap more reliable. Comment out two lines in the code by placing "//" without the quotes, at the beginning of the lines; "wifiSetup();" in the void setup() function (line 244), and "wifiClient();" in the void loop() function (line 260).

My 56mm EP arrived with only a plastic bag over it so I made some caps for it as well as a spacer. The cover for the eyecup is designed to go on with the eyecup folded over. The 10mm spacer keeps it from going too far into my Baader diagonal.

Notes:

Print the body in the lying position so that the grain is parallel to the flight axis.

Den Körper im liegen drucken, damit der Faserverlauf parallel zur Flugachse ist.

comments.text: I would ensure the batteries are fully charged if you're using re-chargables (I did with mine), or use some fresh ones if they are single use batteries. Batteries that are not at there peak can fail to heat the wire up enough.

The design is a simple ducted blower (radial) extruder fan which can be used to focus cooling exactly on the extruder nozzle area. The assembly uses: - A 50mm x 15mm 12v DC blower fan model 5015S - A short length (about 80mm) of flexible ducting cut from 10mm outside diameter electrical conduit - A short length (about 70mm) of heavy gauge copper wire (ie about 1.8mm thick from some scrap power cable) - A couple of small printed ABS parts The photos show the assembly components and the blower fan mounted on the Wade extruder. In this case the printer is a Robo 3D The parts are an interference fit in the blower outlet or can be glued/siliconed. The fan assembly is screwed tightly to the unused screw hole on the extruder stepper motor and can be adjusted up/down. Adjust the length of the duct and angle of the copper wire to focus the cooling. To make sure the assembly moves only when you want it to, use a rubber washer(or similar) between the fan and the stepper motor. There are no other mods to the extruder assembly required and the stock fan should not need to be removed. A extra pair of light duty wires needs to be run back through the extruder loom to the Ramps fan connection terminals. Might be useful to have a switch to turn each (or both) fans on/off.

comments.text: The extruder gears are molded ABS and are provided as part of The Robo 3D printer. In fact all of the plastic components on the Robo are high quality molded parts.  The Robo guys may be willing to sell spare parts.

print_settings.Notes:: 50% infill for the fence

description.text:
This is a specialized remix of Botmaster's excellent Razor Guillotine redesigned for cutting ptfe bowden tubes.
It produces a clean, square cut without any crushing of the tubing.

You will need:
2 4m 50mm hex head shoulder bolts
2 4m nuts
1 3m 15-20mm screw
1 3m nut
2 springs
1 single edge razor blade

I can't give any specs on the springs because, like Botmaster, I used springs I already had from an assortment.
The CAD files could be modified to use different (non-metric) hardware pretty easily.

After printing the base I chased the tubing hole with a #19 drill. A 4mm or 4.1mm drill should also work. The size of the hole can readily be changed in the openscad file. If desired it could even be adapted for a bowden for 3mm filament.

The razor blade slides into the carrier from the side before assembly. The shoulder bolts are threaded in from the top, engaging the nuts in the bottom of the base. I added the Fence_knobs for two reasons. It makes assembly/disassembly easier when replacing the razor blade (which, considering you're only cutting ptfe, will be seldom if ever). More importantly, it also acts as a spacer so that the edge of the razor blade is never exposed.

Assemble the fence screw by placing a 3m nut in the recess and tighten a 3m screw from the other side. There should never be much torque placed on this part so there is little chance of this unscrewing in normal use.

If you customize this with the openscad design you'll need the origial base stl from Botmaster's original Razor Guillotine.

The design of the wallclock "FatFour" features a uncommon implementation of numbers and dots that – other than with classic inlay – made from very thick material. Actually so thick that you can clearly see this from the side. I used 20 mm oak for dots and numbers and 5 mm pvc-hardfoam for the dial itself. The clockwork is a simple quartz movement you get of eBay. The clock hands are covered with wood veneer.

The drawing was made using Illustrator. Fusion360 helped to verify the design as it renders a representation before wasting valuable material.

The build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Clocks for more interesting clock designs.

author: FritzWe

title: Boat gasoline tank adapter 90°- 90° Benzintankadapter Boot

description.text:
I bought a new 50l petrol tank for my boat and attached it to the bow region. To fill the tank I decided to apply a gas pump nozzle adapter in the GFK-Shell with a petrol stable tube (inner diameter 38mm).

All connecting parts I could find on the www didn't fit on top of the tank. So I decided to test the Petrol+2stroke oil constancy of PLA-> works great.

This THING is a custom solution for the original tank cover(blue), a 90° 1 1/2 " tube and a three-step adapter (37.5mm, 50mm, 58mm).

it was hard to measure the original thread so I designed some test prints in a couple of iterations for both threads ( cover & 90° tube).

In the top section, i provided a 16mm tube adapter for the tank vent and also an infill guide to avoid petrol leaks.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.45

Infill:

25%

title: .grip modular Modell and Miniature painting Handle and Vice with PCO 1881 Cap Support

description.text:
.grip is a multifunctional Tool for your Hobby. It´s not just a simple Paint Handle with a Hand Rest, it´s also a mini Vice for Pieces with irregular Shapes oder uncommon sizes.

On first time Use, gently srew on the vice or Cap Holder, slightly turn it back and forth until it´s fastened. So you don´t ruin the Screw.

For the Vice assembly you need two rubber Bands. Watch the Pictures to learn how to build the Vice, but it should be self explainig.

Instead of Printing the Pins, you can use M4 Bolts.

On the Bottle Cap Mount you can use most standard screw Bottle Caps.
If you wan´t some more Bottle Caps, you can Print them too, just head over to JBijnens Bottle Caps. They work Perfect with .grip https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:806488

12/26/2017
Added a Second Ring (ring-big.stl) for better using the Hand rest with the vice.

12/16/2017
Innitial Release

description.text:
Replacement handle for print scraper.

If you're like me, you probably have the same (or similar) tool for removing your prints. I got it because I needed one, and it wasn't very expensive. In fact, the tool I purchased is actually sold as an artists painting tool. The same exact tool, when sold for 3D printing, is about 2 or even 3 times the price.

After a a couple of years of using it, I applied a little much torque and broke the handle.

At first, I was like..... I have a piece of hardwood dowel, I'll cut a hunk off, drill a hole and I'll be back in business.

Then I was like.... duh! I have a 3D printer..... let's make something instead!

It's a simple design with slight depressions for your thumb on one side and fingers on the other.

I have a set of screwdrivers that are red and black on each end, so I manually made filament changes to change the colors so it would be similar to the screwdrivers.

I printed this in PETG and increased the number of perimeters and tops/bottom to increase strength.

I also used 2 processes in Simplify3D to change perimeters/floors and the infill of the handle at different heights. Most of the handle was done at 25% infill with 4 perimeters and floors. The tool end (about 35mm) I increased the infill to 85% and 6 perimeters. I did this to increase the strength on the tool end, and to give me enough material around the hole to allow for drilling and inserting the tool.

Basically, I drilled out the hole to just slightly smaller than the diameter of the tool rod, heated the tool rod up and pushed it into the hole.

I've included the SketchUp model in case you'd like to make modifications.

Printer:

Anycubic Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

Varies

Notes:

Printed on end without supports.
Slow your speed down so the handle doesn't wobble as the height increases.

Drill the hole slightly deeper than the tool rod. There needs to be some space at the bottom of the hole for melted plastic.

The tool rod doesn't need to be red hot to be inserted. I used a lighter for about 60 seconds and it worked fine.
Designed in SketchUp 2017.

print_settings.Notes:: Use any print setting you wish to examine. But you should not rotate the object

description.text:
This simple test cube helps to analyze the ringing on your printer. It has six distinct faces with lots of 90° edges to induce high stress on the drive of x and y axis. This also helps to maintain orientation of printing while comparing different samples.

If your printer suffers from ringing, you will see, waves on the surface starting from a corner.

On the top and bottom are small round indents witch will show the hysteresis in the drive. If your printer suffers from tolerances in the positioning, these holes will be deformed to ovals.

If your printer is suffering from random slag the vertical edges will be rough.

Notes:

Use any print setting you wish to examine. But you should not rotate the object

title: 3-1 Speed mutiplier for remote direct drive

description.text:
So I remade this because it works well, and the bearing holes weren't the right size and I wanted a way to clamp down on the tubing. Place some supports under the clamping part.

https://youtu.be/MwEhKZO7G10

I printed mine with super dry taulman bridge nylon, 3 walls, 4 bottom layers, 5 top layers onto watered down 3d eez on a build plate @ 90C, print temperature 288C.

Reference original design for BOM.

I also added some precision shims (openbuilds) but washers should also work well - the point is to clamp down on the bearings so they are stable.

The bolt used is a 5mmx15mm - with a lock nut.

also included are cad files for folks use out there.

comments.text: hey - the cad files are there. And the BOM is on OCD3D's page. Nothing stopping you from switching the pulleys. Also its not a leadscrew - its more of a steel flexable cable. Look up Flex3Drive and Zesty nimble. The are interesting technology.
comments.author: Pr1mus285

comments.text: with a remote direct drive - there is a 30:1 or a 40:1 reduction happening via worm gear and gear downstream.  Stepper motors don't like running at 3K RPM. This is so I can move and retract at normal human being speeds with a remote direct drive. I dont need more torque - I need more RPM's - and the torque falloff with RPM's was killing me.
comments.author: Pr1mus285

comments.text: Ahh okay. I was planning on designing something similar to increase torque. I watched the linked video in the design and it looked like it was pushing the leadscrew pretty hard so I saw the potential for skipped steps and assumed the worst.
comments.author: Pr1mus285

comments.text: You know you're losing torque with this design. if you switched the gears to be small side on the motor and big side on the leadscrew you would increase your torque and make your movements more accurate. This would be more prone to skipped steps because the motor is having to spin less and push harder.  Kind of like riding a bicycle. the smaller the gear in the front and bigger the gear in the back, the easier it is to pedal.
comments.author: dfmsguitar

comments.text: I've been printing with my original design now for a while... there are no issues at all. I think I have several videos on YouTube showing the performance, but I'm planning to print this remix tonight to replace my originals. I'll record the event.

Cover for F450 frame. It allows you to pack the electronics (FC, telemetry radio , FPV Tx) to protect it and make the drone look neater.

Assembly instructions

insert M3 nuts in four upper corner of the frame. these will counter the screws which protrude the lid.
Use M3 10mm screws to secure the lid.

insert 4 x M3 nuts in the bottom flanges. Use M3 8mm screws with suitable washers from the bottom of the F450 upper board to secure the frame to the Drone's body.

The frame has a forward opening for FPV camera (preferably covered with foam to reduce vibrations).

It also has 2 holes in the lid, one for GPS cable and the other for a safety button.
Also, it has two round holes on the back side - for VTX and telemetry radio antennae.

title: Bryton mount: stem or handlebar options

description.text: This is a Bryton Rider mount for handlebar or stem, tested with my Rider 330. This object was inspired from the original mount and thing:2537865. However I totally redraw the part, including a perfect-fit mounting system which is more suited to 3d-printing than the original one. Mounting to the stem or handlebar are made with two zip-ties.

Printer:

3DMS - Scalar S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Prints well with ABS materials (fan off) and ZIG-ZAG supports, spaced by 1.5mm ("support line distance" in Cura). Please only use zig-zag supports as they are easy to remove, especially in the zip-tie holes. I highly recommend to use supports as the perfect fit of your device totally depends on a 90° overhang.
Print it in the original orientation, that is, the orientation it will be mounted, so that the friction faces are as smooth as possible. The face touching your stem or handlebar will be rough, but nobody should see it once mounted ;-D
Take you time to remove the supports while not damaging the part. Zip-tie holes supports should be removed with a kind of little rod.
Designed with FreeCad 0.16.

author: didierh

description.text:
https://photos.app.goo.gl/MD8N9wMlSnhrU9b23

This is a remix of the Table Tennis Robot from instructables :
https://www.instructables.com/id/Homemade-table-tennis-robot/
The original printed parts can be found here, many of them are used, but what I changed was :
-There is some different type of DIN50 PVC pipe and connectors, so I made some adapter parts when the original ones would not fit to what I bought, this can vary greatly based on the shop .
-The feeder is no longer using the piston and a servo, instead it is using a disc (designed by informer from rhcforum.ro) which is rotated by a stepper controlled by Arduino via an stick driver like the ones used in RAMPS board for 3D printer
-The motors, I changed from the BLDCs used originally to the Mabuchi RS-540 from hobbyking, this is a very cheap, very powerfull motor, also I used 20 A brushed ESCs from Hobbyking which are also very cheap
-The wheels, I used some aluminium hub rubber wheels which are normally used for landing gear on jets on hobbyking, also a 4 mm shaft and bearing si needed and also an axle adapter from 3.17 mm to 4 mm (I also tried printed wheels with 40 mm orings as rubber, but no success, they have horrible vibration, still the stl is available)
-The rotation mechanism for the head is changed, this is based on alvinchua's design from instructables, it is a gear based rotation so no belt is needed
-The original software was taken and then it was changed in order to control the stepper and the new ESCs . Also a BT module was added and an application for Android was made in order to control the robot

Here are the links to the alternative parts that I used :

The parts that I use will work with some additional printed parts and hardware that I listed into my project .

Hope this helps you .

https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigy-20a-brushed-esc.html

https://hobbyking.com/en_us/mabuchi-rs-540sh-6527-brushed-motor-90w.html

https://hobbyking.com/en_us/brass-motor-transmission-connector-4mm-3-17mmxd9xh20mm-5pcs.html

print_settings.Notes:: Take care to print the parts in the correct orientation, some .stl-Files need to be rotated to be printed correctly. (StabilizationPlate 90 degrees, Clamp 180 degrees)

description.text: This is a WaterRocketLauncher for launching water bottles.

Printer:

Davinci 1.1 plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

90-100%

Notes:

WARNING!! Take care and wear at least safetyglasses when things get under pressure. It is hard to tell how much force a 3D-printed part will survive as this depends on your used material and printer settings. Be prepared for the case something breaks!

If you choose to mount it on a baseplate around 3-12mm thickness you dont need to print a baseplate (there are 3 different versions) and mostly no "VentilGuide".
If your baseplate has under 5mm you may want to print out and use the "VentilGuide"
Depending on the thickness of your used baseplate and if you use a HolderExtension you may have to use longer screws than the stated M3x20.

A HolderExtension is needed if you cannot find a bottle suitable for the original length of the holder.

Baseplates, HolderExtendsion and VentilGuide are optional, you need at least the Holder, Clamp, StabilizationPlate, Stabilizer and Clip.

Take care to print the parts in the correct orientation, some .stl-Files need to be rotated to be printed correctly. (StabilizationPlate 90 degrees, Clamp 180 degrees)

What you need
  • Printed Parts
  • Bicycle tube including the ventile
  • Screws (6xM3x20, 1xM3x25, 9xM3 Nut, 2xM3 Washer 3,2mm DIN125 )
  • Springs (two or if you have a long one cut it into two pieces)
  • Something to mount the rocketlauncher on, up to your creativity what you use
  • Maybe some pressure tube to get some distance between you and the launchpad :)
Preparation

Cut the bicycle tube the way that you get the ventile including a circle of tube around it that fits into the holder printed before.
Redrill the holes with a 3mm drill to ensure that the M3 screws fit into the holes

Assembly

Put a spring on the ventile and place it into the holder. Depends on the spring you use, if you find it not stable, try to add a washer between the spring and the ventile/tube-part.
Mount the StabilizerPlate, Clamps, Stabilizer and Holder together as shown on the image. Don`t tighten the screws of the Clamps too much. It should move easy to securely launch the rocket later.
You can use some grease maybe if it is needed. Also it may be a good idea to use 2 nuts or some screwlock glue to prevent the nuts from loosening themselves due to clamp movement.

Flying extruder mount for my Anycubic Kossel Linear Plus

It is madee to fit a standard NEMA17 Stepper motor so the size may be reduced if you use a pancake stepper.

Fusion 360

http://a360.co/2ooPdEX

comments.text:
Scaled down to 90% and fit is a bit tight! If I try again I will scale the outer to 90% and inner to 88~89%
Some sandpaper should help things out too.
Another tip, I printed at 0.38mm layer height and the "coarseness" of the layers at that resolution is providing a significant amount of added friction. Keeping it lower will reduce sliding friction of the part, (straight off the plate).
Also, ANOTHER thing, I would recommend keeping the initial layer height roughly the same as the rest to maintain higher resolution of the notches on that end of the tubes.
Love the idea tho! Hopefully it will keep the cat from jumping on my leg asking for food all the time!

title: Titan Aero carriage for Anet A8

description.text:
A fully-printed mount for the Titan Aero extruder. It uses printed bearing bushes, along the lines of this one. If you're printing these for the first time err on the side of making them a bit loose rather than too tight. They will loosen up a little after several hours of printing.

The main carriage is printed in one piece, and seems to work well. It has a few mounting points for cables, etc. I planned to attach the part fooling fan opposite the extruder, but with a large blower, there wasn't enough space. I reverted to the stock blower since the big one didn't generate much pressure.

The fan duct here is a placeholder. Ping me if you need a working one, I think I have a usable design now.

I'm using the stock ANET board. This means you need to keep the old stepper since the anet board doesn't seme to have the current to drive a low-profile stepper.

You need to reverse both the extruder drive, and the X-axis drive. You also need to be able to adjust Z about 20mm lower than with the stock setup. This may help.

Bear in mind that you will loose 15mm of Y travel using this setup, but it's a big improvement. I'm able to print 200x200 at least with the oversized bushing shown.

author: tsh2

description.text: A shrunken xersion of my optical endstop mount, to work with the Titan Aero mount which protrudes less far below the rails. The motor mount can be relaxed a little (and made stronger), but it does work like this.

print_settings.Notes:: Designed to be printed without supports.

title: Intake tract/funnel for print cooling fan

description.text:
A funnel/intake tract for the print fan.
By gradually decreasing the cross-sectional area leading down to the intake of the fan, the performance of the performance of the fan should increase. This is however most probably grossly oversized so the main benefit from it is that it looks cool.

EDIT: With my setup of this intake tract and my duct, I can print small parts (30mm long pasta screw) completely without artifacts that I could not print without "ugliness" on the backside due to insufficient cooling without the intake tract and with the original fan duct. Also, I've turned the normal cooling down from 85% to 50%.

TIP: To reduce noise due to vibrations, add some weak, thin, doublesided tape between the fan and the extruder body and between the nozzle and the fan around the outside (Not on the middle part).

description.text:
I thought it would be handy to have a fidget on a pencil. This is designed for a standard, #2 pencil.

Supports are required but are very easy to remove. The support will usually only be on the ring and nearly comes off on it's own when you remove it from the build plate.

If it is difficult to install, slide it on from the sharpened end of the pencil, not the eraser end. Also, twist the pencil in the same direction as the small ribs inside of the fidget.

Please post your makes and comments.

20%

Installation

If it is difficult to install, slide it on from the sharpened end, not the eraser end. Also, twist the pencil in the same direction as the small ribs inside of the fidget.

comments.text: Is the ribbed ring supposed to spin? It looks like it should in the pictures, but mine does not.
comments.author: wmorgan

comments.text: Yes, it should spin. Did you print it with supports? I needs them. Also, you might have too high of an extrusion multiplier if it's fused. The clearance isn't a lot so your machine has to be tuned pretty well. I printed with a 0.04mm nozzle and I'm always set at 97% extrusion multiplier. I got fused parts when I printed with 100% extrusion multiplier.
comments.author: wmorgan

comments.text: Thank you! I am very new to 3D printing, so I am not familiar with how to change the extrusion multiplier. But I will do some research.
